subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}

In the oracle bone script and the early Western Zhou bronze script, it was a {{liushu|p|nocap=1}} of a slave or prisoner, with hands holding a basket ({{zh-l|*其}}) to pick up garbage, an instrument of punishment ({{zh-l|*辛}}) above the head{{,}} and a tail ({{zh-l|*尾}}) to represent the slave's low status, akin to animals.

{{zh-l|*其}} later corrupts into {{zh-l|*甾}}, the hands ({{zh-l|*廾}}) move below {{zh-l|*辛}}, and the slave's body ({{zh-l|*人}}) moves to become the left component. Later, {{zh-l|*辛}} corrupts into {{zh-l|*丵}} (probably by fusing with {{zh-l|*甾}}) and combines with {{zh-l|*廾}} to give {{och-l|菐}}, which functions as a phonetic component.

In the current form, it is essentially a {{Han compound|人|菐|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p|t1=man|nocap=1}}.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Probably related to {{cog|bo|བུ||son; boy}} ({{zh-ref|Coblin, 1986}}).

Alternatively, {{zh-ref|Peiros and Starostin (1996)}} compare it to {{cog|bo|ཕྲུག||child}}.
